content.raw:
Yes, whether or not a value parameter is const does not affect the function signature and therefore does not impact ABI compatibility. In fact, you will get an ODR violation if you try to define both a function `foo(Arg arg)` and a `foo(const Arg arg)`, because they have the same signature within the ABI. Notice how the header declaration of this function has not changed to include a `const`.

This is different from reference parameters, where the const does matter. So `foo(Arg& arg)`, `foo(const Arg& arg)`, and `foo(Arg arg)` all have different function signatures, which means they are different within the ABI.

Edit: ODE --> ODR (One Definition Rule) ....I've been too immersed in ODE lately.
content.html:
Yes, whether or not a value parameter is const does not affect the function signature and therefore does not impact ABI compatibility. In fact, you will get an ODR violation if you try to define both a function foo(Arg arg) and a foo(const Arg arg), because they have the same signature within the ABI. Notice how the header declaration of this function has not changed to include a const.

This is different from reference parameters, where the const does matter. So foo(Arg& arg), foo(const Arg& arg), and foo(Arg arg) all have different function signatures, which means they are different within the ABI.

Edit: ODE --> ODR (One Definition Rule) ....I've been too immersed in ODE lately.
